title: Travel briefs
text:
Columbus, Ohio • Aug 16, 2015 • 71° Clear The Columbus Dispatch Need help? Visit our FAQ page or use our Contact Form . Customer Service Need help? Try our live chat or online customer service . For service, call 1-877-734-7728. For other inquiries, use our Contact Form or Staff Directory . Subscriptions Subscribe to The Dispatch online or call 1-877-734-7728. Advertising To place help wanted ads, call 614-888-8888 or visit ColumbusJobs.com For private seller and classified advertising, call 614-888-8888 or visit DispatchClassifieds.com . For retail advertising, call 614-461-5500 or email us . For national advertising, call 614-461-5199. For online advertising, call 614-461-5143 or email us . Newsroom Use our Contact Form , or call 614-461-5200. Dispatch Careers Visit dispatch.com/careers or call 614-461-5033. Fax 614-461-5565. Sunday August 16, 2015 5:00 AM Bucyrus meets its past 
Visitors can meet the “founders” of Bucyrus from 1 to 5 p.m. Aug. 30 during the Bucyrus Historic Cemetery Walk. 
The free interactive walk will feature re-enactors portraying the people who helped build the Ohio city. 
For information, call 1-866-562-0720 or visit www.bucyrus.org D-Day to be re-enacted 
More than 900 people in period uniforms will re-enact D-Day at an event Thursday through Saturday at Conneaut Township Park in Conneaut, Ohio. 
The free D-Day Ohio event, held on the park’s 250-yard long beach on Lake Erie and adjacent sloping terrain, will involve authentic World War II-era military vehicles and machinery, including amphibious landing craft and a Sherman tank. The event will also include a dance with a live big band, encampments of Allied “troops,” combat re-enactments and more. 
Almost 25,000 people visited last year’s event. 
Call 440-593-2402 or visit www.ddayohio.us Stewart set donated 
The set of The Daily Show With Jon Stewart will be donated to the Newseum in Washington, D.C. 
Newseum spokesman Jonathan Thompson said the museum will acquire the set of the Comedy Central satirical newscast — including the desk, globe and props. IMAX to get parks film 
A new 3-D film about America’s national parks will hit IMAX theaters next year with Robert Redford as its narrator. 
The film, National Parks Adventure , is scheduled for release in February to coincide with the centennial of the National Park Service. 
The movie, featuring mountaineer Conrad Anker and others visiting parks, will be shown in IMAX theaters worldwide.
